awd_titl_txt: Arabidopsis 2010: Protein Interacting Networks and Site-Specific Phosphorylation in Leucine-Rich Repeat Receptor-Like Kinase Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant and animal cells sense and respond to signals in their environment through receptors that relay biochemical information via protein-protein interactions to the nucleus, where changes in gene expression occur. One class of these receptors (the Leucine-Rich Repeat Receptor-like kinases or LRR RLKs) is present in a large family of 223 members in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. These receptors have a structural organization similar to that of animal receptor kinases, and several that have been studied in detail are known to be critical elements that regulate the plant's growth, morphogenesis, disease resistance, and responses to stress. However, the functions of the vast majority of this large family of signal transduction molecules remain unknown. With previous support from the NSF Arabidopsis 2010 Program, the investigators have generated a set of genetic and biochemical resources that will allow the in-depth study of the function of LRR RLKs in plant growth and stress responses. Using proteomic and mass spectrometry approaches, this project is designed to define the proteins that interact with these LRR RLKs. These proteins form an interactive network whose function ultimately determines a range of physiological responses, and this project will define the components and properties of this network. In addition to this broad study of protein network interactions, a selected group of LRR-RLKs will be characterized at a detailed biochemical level, including functional analyses that will permit an understanding of how these proteins influence plant growth.

Broader Impact of the Research: 
Given the known importance of the LRR RLK family to plant development, the results of this project are likely to have practical agricultural impact. In addition this project will provide extensive resources to the Arabidopsis research community including a database (http://www4.ncsu.edu/~sclouse/Clouse2010.htm) that creates a unique resource for the comparative study of LRR RLK protein networks and phosphorylation sites. The highly successful NSF-supported Plant Phosphorylation Workshop will be reinitiated and will serve as a forum for researchers from as many as 45 laboratories to interact and share research ideas and results. The project will also provide training in protein biochemistry, mass spectrometry, and Arabidopsis molecular genetics at all levels from high school student interns through postdoctoral scientists. Recruitment of these individuals will be integrated with established programs at North Carolina State University and the University of Illinois that encourage the participation of under-represented minorities in scientific research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Plants respond to developmental and environmental signals in part through membrane-localized receptor kinases that interact with other proteins to initiate a cascade of biochemical events resulting in altered cellular function. The genome of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana encodes 223 Leucine-Rich Repeat Receptor-Like Kinases (LRR RLKs) with a structural organization similar to that of animal receptor kinases. Several of these plant LRR RLKs have been characterized in some detail and are known to play critical roles in regulating growth, morphogenesis, disease resistance, and responses to stress signals. Key to understanding LRR RLK action in specific signaling pathways is the identification of both membrane-bound and soluble protein partners. Furthermore, reversible phosphorylation of receptor kinases leads to critical modulation of numerous plant signal transduction pathways and identification of specific phosphorylation sites in LRR RLKs is critical to understanding the detailed mechanisms of their function. The investigators in this project generated a tool set of genetic and biochemical resources and developed optimized protocols for protein interaction studies and phosphorylation site identification. Using interdisciplinary approaches from plant genetics, biochemistry, mass spectrometry and proteomics, an extensive network of more than 800 LRR RLK interacting proteins was generated.  Besides a broad study of protein interactions, a selected group of LRR RLKs was functionally characterized at a detailed biochemical level, including those LRR RLKs interacting with calcium-binding proteins such as calmodulin. This project also provided extensive LRR RLK resources to the Arabidopsis research community including an internet database of more than 500 phosphorylation sites across 68 LRR RLKs (http://www4.ncsu.edu/~sclouse/Clouse2010.htm), creating a unique resource for comparative study. The interdisciplinary approaches combining plant biology with mass spectrometry techniques generated new knowledge and approaches applicable to other investigators studying plant protein interactions. Receptor kinases control many aspects of plant growth and development as well as responses to the environment and understanding their signaling mechanisms will likely have downstream applications in regulating yield in various crop plants.

This project also provided excellent training in protein biochemistry, mass spectrometry, and Arabidopsis molecular genetics to more than a dozen individuals at all levels from undergraduates through postdoctoral scientists. Moreover, the project funded two Plant Protein Phosphorylation Workshops (2011 and 2012) that exposed 84 PIs, 45 postdoctoral scientists, and 45 graduate students to a wide spectrum of work in the field of kinases and phosphatases and gave the opportunity for many junior members to present their data in front of a scientific audience. The workshops offered exceptional opportunities for young scientists to learn presentation skills, to meet and network with their peers, including detailed discussions of methods and techniques, and to engage in informal discussions with leaders in the plant phosphorylation field, which extends mentoring opportunities beyond that of their individual advisors.


Last Modified: 10/01/2015
Modified by: Steven D Clouse
